page.title: 11FISHING IN THE CUT
page.content: The "Cut" is the Bridgewater Canal. This was built in the eighteenth century by the Duke of Bridgewater to carry coal from his mines at Worsley to the River Mersey at Runcorn. Now it is only used for recreation. Many people have canal barges which chug through Lymm and Grappenhall along the "Cut". Some people live on the boats all the time and many of the boats are brightly painted. Fishing is also very popular along the canal. A large variety of fish can be caught including carp, rudd, perch, tench and roach. The best time to fish in the summer is between 8 and 1O pm when the fish are feeding.
